history.content: Given that the numerator is a fixed constant $$e$$ and the denominator $$\log n$$ is growing with $$n$$ (i.e. the whole number gets smaller as $$n$$ gets larger), I think the constant $$\frac{1}{4}$$ was chosen as a bound somewhat arbitrarily to make the numbers nice: when the log is base $$2$$, the probability that bin $$B_i$$ gets load $$\geq \log n$$ becomes $$\leq \frac{1}{n^2}$$. Also, the professor mentioned that $$\frac{1}{4}$$ is a good bound when $$\log n \geq 4e$$, which happens when $$n > 2^{11} = 2,048$$, which is easily true in our case because we have a large $$n$$.

I think the constant $$\frac{1}{4}$$ was chosen somewhat arbitrarily to make the numbers nice: when the log is base $$2$$, the probability that bin $$B_i$$ gets load $$\geq \log n$$ becomes $$\leq \frac{1}{n^2}$$. Also, the professor mentioned that $$\frac{1}{4}$$ is a good bound when $$\log n \geq 4e$$, which happens when $$n > 2^{11} = 2,048$$, which is easily true in our case because we have a large $$n$$.

I think the constant $$\frac{1}{4}$$ was chosen somewhat arbitrarily to make the numbers nice: when the log is base $$2$$, the probability that bin $$B_i$$ gets load $$\geq \log n$$ becomes $$\leq \frac{1}{n^2}$$. Also, the professor mentioned that $$\frac{1}{4}$$ is a good bound because it's true when $$\log n \geq 4e$$, which happens when $$n > 2^{11} = 2,048$$, which is easily true in our case because we have a large $$n$$.

children.subject: My understanding of the lecture is the same as Dennis's explanation above.

history.content: Dennis is right, it's a nice explanation.  The quantity $$\frac{e}{\log{n}}$$ is much smaller than what I need.  By choosing $$n>2^{4e}$$ we have that it's $$< 1/4$$.  That's good enough for me.  If I wanted smaller I could look at $$n>2^{16e}$$ and it's $$<1/16$$.  It's like O() notation, we're just proving things for all sufficiently large n.  Once I have that it's $$<1/4$$ then we can use that $$(1/4)^{\log{n}} = 1/n^2$$.

Dennis is right, it's a nice explanation.  The quantity $$\frac{e}{\log{n}}$$ is much smaller than what I need.  By choosing $$n>2^{4e}$$ we have that it's $$< 1/4$$.  That's good enough for me.  If I wanted smaller I could look at $n>2^{16e}$ and it's $$<1/16$$.  It's like O() notation, we're just proving things for all sufficiently large n.  Once I have that it's $$<1/4$$ then we can use that $$(1/4)^{\log{n}} = 1/n^2$$.

If I wanted smaller I could look at $n>2^{16e}$ and it's $$<1/16$.  It's like O() notation, we're just proving things for all sufficiently large n.  Once I have that it's $$<1/4$$ then we can use that $$(1/4)^{\log{n}) = 1/n^2$$.

Hello,

I am having trouble understanding how the lecture video came to conclusion to use (1/4)^logN.

I understand how we have (e/logN)^logN, but after that it doesn't make sense how the professor came his conclusion of 1/n^2.

Can someone try to explain it to me?
history.subject: RA3 - Bloom Filters
